qas.question: Who settled in parts of England?
Polabian-Pomeranian Slavs are also known to have even settled where?
What refers to the Slavic mercenaries and slaves in the medieval Arab world in North Africa, Sicily and Al-Andalus?
What is another name for Iceland?
What name refers to the Polabian-Pomeranian Slavs?
Who served as the guards of the Saqaliba?
When did the Polabian Slavs settle in England?
When did Niklot invade Slavic lands?

context: <a0_0>Polabian Slavs (Wends)<a0_0/> settled in <a1_0>parts of England (<b5_0>Danelaw<b5_0/>)<a1_0/>, apparently as Danish allies. Polabian-Pomeranian Slavs are also known to have even settled on <a2_0>Norse age Iceland<a2_0/>. <a3_0><b6_0>Saqaliba<b6_0/><a3_0/> refers to the Slavic mercenaries and slaves in the medieval Arab world in North Africa, Sicily and Al-Andalus. Saqaliba served as <a4_0><b7_0>caliph<b7_0/>'s guards<a4_0/>. In <b8_0>the 12th century<b8_0/>, there was intensification of Slavic piracy in the Baltics. The Wendish Crusade was started against the Polabian Slavs in <b9_0>1147<b9_0/>, as a part of the Northern Crusades. Niklot, pagan chief of the Slavic Obodrites, began his open resistance when Lothar III, Holy Roman Emperor, invaded Slavic lands. In August 1160 Niklot was killed and German colonization (Ostsiedlung) of the Elbe-Oder region began. In Hanoverian Wendland, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern and Lusatia invaders started germanization. Early forms of germanization were described by German monks: Helmold in the manuscript Chronicon Slavorum and Adam of Bremen in Gesta Hammaburgensis ecclesiae pontificum. The Polabian language survived until the beginning of the 19th century in what is now the German state of Lower Saxony. In Eastern Germany, around 20% of Germans have Slavic paternal ancestry. Similarly, in Germany, around 20% of the foreign surnames are of Slavic origin.
